urn:contentItem:5X3G-RNM1-F03R-N3S2-00000-0012 Gen Zers who skipped school to march across New York for the Global Climate Strike share why this is the most urgent issue of their generation2019-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:41ZLexisNexis12 Gen Zers who skipped school to march across New York for the Global Climate Strike share why this is the most urgent issue of their generationIvan De Luce

Sep 20, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Ivan De Luce/Business Insider An estimated 250,000 demonstrators gathered at Manhattan's Foley Square on Friday for the Global Climate Strike[1] — and most of them were Gen Zers[2]. The catalyst for the march, 16-year-old climate activist Greta Thunberg[3], has become an inspiration for the young generation passionate about climate change. Business Insider spoke with Gen Z demonstrators at the strike to find out what they had to say about the demonstration, Thunberg, and the dangers of ignoring climate change. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[4]. Young people around the world[5] are on strike. An estimated 250,000 demonstrators gathered at Foley Square in Manhattan on Friday as part of the Global Climate Strike[6]. New York is just one of hundreds of cities in 156 countries and regions (including Antarctica) with thousands of protesters filling the streets.

For the most part, they've all been students[7]. New York's Education Department let students skip class[8] to join the ranks in the march, which began at 12:30 pm, making its way down Broadway toward Battery Park[9]. Despite students getting the city's permission to attend the strike, teachers were barred from it to avoid political influence in the classroom. One of the main reasons Gen Zers are passionate about climate change is Greta Thunberg[10], a 16-year-old Swedish climate activist who gained worldwide attention after skipping school to protest in front of Stockholm's parliament building last year. Since then, she has met with former President Barack Obama, sailed across the Atlantic Ocean[11] to lower her carbon footprint, and been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize[12]. Here's what Gen Zers had to say about the strike, Thunberg, and the dangers of ignoring climate change. Sophie, a 19-year-old, said that Greta Thunberg is an inspiration for her. Ivan De Luce/Business Insider"I'm really passionate about helping the environment, and it's something that needs to happen," Sophie told Business Insider. "We've gone so long with just people not doing anything about it, and it's time." Sophie also talked about what Thunberg means to her. "I'm so excited. She's so inspiring. She is a symbol of everything — she's inspiring to young women. She's what we need right now."Estella and Bella, who go to the Chapin School in the Upper East Side, were also fans of Thunberg. Ivan De Luce/Business Insider"She's really just such an inspiration, and I just really want to help save the Earth," Estella said. "I think that she has such a platform to help spread that." "She doesn't care what [people] think. She's ready to tell them what they need to hear," said Bella.Two seventh graders, Barrett and Isabella, liked the way Thunberg stressed the importance of listening to scientists about climate change. Ivan De Luce/Business Insider"Everyone on this planet, if they want to keep it, has to make a difference," Barrett (pictured left) said. "We can't vote yet, we can't really do much because we're young, so this is our way to do something." "Everyone has made a big mistake wasting plastic, cutting down so many trees, and ruining the Earth at this point," Isabella (pictured right) said. "We're trying to make our change." Isabella and Barrett spoke about why they support Thunberg's activism. "I think she means courage and strength," Isabella said. "She's just such an inspirational girl." "She's so brave," Barrett said. "It shows that age doesn't matter with what you can do."See the rest of the story at Business Insider[13] See Also: Don't break up Big Tech, says Bill Gates. The world's second-richest man says regulation is the way forward — and he's speaking from experience.[14]California's gig economy bill won't just impact Uber drivers. Here's how the landmark decision is a major win for janitors, truck drivers, and other low-wage workers.[15]Meet WeWork's board of directors, a group of former execs guiding founder Adam Neumann through a flubbed IPO[16] SEE ALSO:The most creative signs from New York's Global Climate Strike have one message in common: Time's running out[17] [ 1]: urn:contentItem:5WWD-3N81-DYTN-N1WJ-00000-0012 Tech Stocks That Wall Street Loves the Most2019-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:42ZLexisNexis12 Tech Stocks That Wall Street Loves the Mostdan burrows, contributing writer, kiplinger.com

Markets have been so volatile this summer on U.S.-China trade tensions that investors might not have noticed: Tech stocks are absolutely red-hot in 2019.

Indeed, the technology sector of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is leading the broader market by a mile this year, with a year-to-date gain of 29% through Aug. 21. By comparison, the S&P 500 is up about 17%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index has risen 21%. (The second-best performing sector is real estate, up 25%.)

Stellar gains are always welcome, but they do pose a challenge for investors. After such a big run-up, is there anything left worth buying at current levels?

Analyst sure think so. Between momentum and the sector's outsize growth prospects, plenty of tech stocks have nowhere near topped out, they say.

To see which picks analysts like best at this point, we screened the Nasdaq Composite for the top-rated small, midsize and large tech stocks. S&P Global Market Intelligence surveys analysts' ratings on stocks and scores them on a five-point scale, where 1.0 equals Strong Buy and 5.0 means Strong Sell. Any score of 2.0 or lower means that analysts, on average, rate the stock a Buy. The closer the score gets to 1.0, the better.

Here are the 12 tech stocks the analysts love right now. This group is broken down into the four best-rated stock picks in the small-, mid- and large-cap spaces.

SEE ALSO: All 30 Dow Stocks Ranked: The Analysts Weigh In

Top-Rated Small Tech Stock #4: Varonis Systems

Market value: $2.1 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.86

Analysts think highly of Varonis Systems' (VRNS, $70.28) strategic plan.

Like many tech stocks, the cybersecurity software company is transitioning away from selling licenses and toward a cloud-based subscription model. Although pivoting to software-as-a-service is rarely pain-free - VRNS' revenue fell 4% in Q2 - such transitions boost margins over the long haul.

At the same time, VRNS is benefitting from new regulations on digital privacy such as the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), stricter compliance requirements and the " ominous threat environment," write Wedbush analysts, who rate shares at Outperform (equivalent to Buy).

" In the numerous software business model transitions we have seen play out over the past decade, we can never remember seeing a company so quickly ramp subscription revenues in the course of a few quarters, which speaks to a massive success story so far for the company (and its investors)," Wedbush writes.

Of the 14 analysts covering the stock tracked by S&P Global Market Intelligence, seven rate VRNS at Strong Buy, two say Buy and five call it a Hold. Their average target price of $81.46 gives Varonis implied upside of 16% over the next 12 months or so.

SEE ALSO: The Best Online Brokers, 2019

Top-Rated Small Tech Stock #3: Brooks Automation

Market value: $2.3 billion

Dividend yield: 1.3%

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.40

Brooks Automation (BRKS, $32.03) has a good thing going. It's well-established in the semiconductor, solar, and chemical industries, among others, supplying clients with   specialized, high-tech equipment. But it's the firm's emergence in the life sciences sector that makes analysts especially bullish on the stock.

BRKS currently has a place among semiconductor and tech stocks. But analysts think it will increasingly be viewed as a life sciences play. That should help boost price-to-earnings ratios over time, and in turn, lift shares.

" We continue to view Brooks as one of the most compelling valuation stories with regards to Life Science investors," write analysts at Janney, who rate shares at Buy. " We view the change in Brooks legacy semi/technology ownership profile will transition to primarily Life Science investors and Brooks' valuation multiple may expand."

Stifel analysts rate shares at Buy, too, citing BRKS' emerging life sciences business, continued outperformance in the semiconductor segment and improved free cash flow generation. " The company continues to outperform overall industry growth rates by a sizable margin, and we believe this is setting the company up for an above-average growth year in 2020," they write.

Analysts' average target price of $42.50 gives BRKS implied upside of about 33% over the next year or so, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence.

SEE ALSO: 10 Small-Cap Growth Stocks Analysts Love the Most

Top-Rated Small Tech Stock #2: Upland Software

Market value: $1.1 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.38

Analysts are quite taken with upstart Upland Software (UPLD, $42.73). The six-year-old software company provides cloud-based work-management software for business customers - a not-uncrowded industry.

What sets UPLD apart, however, is its aggressive strategy for growth.

Upland is constantly on the prowl for mergers and acquisitions (M&A). It's then able to bundle the software services it picks up through M&A. Most recently, the firm bought cloud-based software provider Cimpl on Aug. 22 for $23.1 million in cash and a $2.6 million cash holdback payable in 12 months. (It also announced a guidance upgrade in concert with the acquisition.)

" Our acquisition pipeline is robust, and we are actively pursuing additional opportunities to build out our solution suites," said Jack McDonald, Upland chairman and CEO, in a press release.

William Blair analysts, who rate the tech stock at Outperform, note that enterprise customers increasingly want bundled software, and UPLD enjoyed " record expansion and major customer growth" in Q2. Of the eight analysts covering Upland that are tracked by S&P Global Market Intelligence, five rate the stock a Strong Buy, and three rate it at Buy.

SEE ALSO: 10 Small-Cap Value Stocks Analysts Love the Most

Top-Rated Small Tech Stock #1: Virtusa

Market value: $1.1 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.29

Shares in Virtusa (VRTU, $35.35) were down 17% for the year-to-date through Aug. 21 - vs. a 17% gain for the S&P 500. Analysts spot a bargain.

The company - which provides IT, business consulting and application outsourcing services - posted better-than-expected quarterly results in early August. The firm also gifted investors a share repurchase program of up to $30 million over the next 12 months.

Wedbush analysts rate shares at Outperform, citing Virtusa's potential to take market share and improving margins at its Polaris subsidiary in India. " We continue to expect a combination of pipeline strength, expanding digital mix, and record level pipeline growth in FS vertical to generate above-sector growth this year," they write.

VRTU also wants to make strategic, niche acquisitions, Wedbush notes.

Of the seven analysts covering Virtusa tracked by S&P Global Market Intelligence, five call the stock a Strong Buy and two call them a Buy. Their average price target of $51.50 gives VRTU implied upside of about 46% over the next year or so. Analysts also expect the company to be a profit-growth machine. They forecast average annual earnings expansion of 18% over the next three to five years, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence.

SEE ALSO: The 20 Best Small-Cap Dividend Stocks to Buy

Top-Rated Mid Tech Stock #4: Dropbox

Market value: $7.4 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.94

Dropbox (DBX, $17.92) remains in most analysts' good graces, despite what has been a disappointing run for the cloud-storage service ever since its March 2018 initial public offering.

Indeed, shares were off more than 12% for the year-to-date through Aug. 21 and now sit below their $21 IPO price. DBX beat Wall Street's quarterly profit and revenue estimates in early August, but shares still tumbled as much as 14% on the report. Weaker-than-expected billings were blamed for the selloff.

Although the stock appears to have recently stabilized, it's been a tough run for the bulls.

" It's frustrating to face nearly ceaseless negativity and middling performance of the stock, but it is more frustrating to try to argue against arguments that the missing of some unguided number or deceleration of a favorite metric reflects anything other than the normal stochastic nature of real-life business operations," write Canaccord Genuity analysts. " We're willing to stick with this name with a Buy rating and push back on the negative knights who say Ni."

The broader analyst community is mixed but lean bullish. Eight analysts tracked by S&P Global Market Intelligence rate DBX at Strong Buy, and three have it at Buy. But three say it's a Hold and another two say to sell Dropbox. Overall, however, their $29.64 target price gives DBX whopping implied upside of 65% - among the highest on this list of tech stocks. Earnings growth is projected to grow an average of 34% annually for the next three to five years.

SEE ALSO: 10 Top-Rated Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy Now

Top-Rated Mid Tech Stock #3: Proofpoint

Market value: $6.6 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.54

Proofpoint (PFPT, $117.60) easily topped the Street's profit and revenue estimates when it posted second-quarter results in late July. The cybersecurity company, which enjoyed a 17% increase in billings, is seeing increased benefits from bundling cloud-based services for clients.

" We see Proofpoint as the leading cloud email security vendor, offering customers a best-of-breed messaging security solution," write Stifel analysts, who rate shares at Buy. " In addition, the company has been one of the more successful acquirers within the group, leveraging M&A to drive sustained greater-than-market growth."

Proofpoint is outperforming tech stocks as a whole, up about 40% so far in 2019 versus 29% for the sector. The pros expect more performance ahead. Their average target price of $144.50 gives PFPT stock implied upside of about 23% over the next year or so.

Analysts expect Proofpoint to grow profits at 26% annually on average over the next three to five years. Twenty-nine analysts are covering PFPT at the moment - 18 rate it a Strong Buy, seven say it's a Buy and the remaining four call it a Hold.

SEE ALSO: The Disruptors: 10 Innovative and Irritating Stock Picks

Top-Rated Mid Tech Stock #2: Viavi Solutions

Market value: $3.2 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.50

Viavi Solutions (VIAV, $13.88) specializes in testing and monitoring various types of communications networks, such as broadband, copper, Wi-Fi and fiber optic. Analysts are bullish on its growth prospects, thanks partly to the rollout of next-generation (5G) wireless networks.

" We continue to believe the company's wireless and fiber test businesses are in the early stages of a multi-year investment cycle as (original equipment manufacturers) and service providers begin their transition to 5G and fiber is deployed deeper into networks," write Stifel analysts, who rate VIAV at Buy.

The company is forecast to generate average annual earnings growth of more than 12% over the next three to five years, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. Analysts average price target of $15.35 gives VIAV implied upside of about 10% over the next year or so - that small relative upside is largely because the stock has been quickly sprinting toward that price target, up 37% year-to-date. Analysts may soon need to re-evaluate and adjust.

Seven analysts rate VIAV at Strong Buy, one says Buy and two have it at Hold, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence.

SEE ALSO: 7 Double-Threat Dividend Stocks in Tech

Top-Rated Mid Tech Stock #1: Lumentum Holdings

Market value: $4.6 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.31

Lumentum Holdings (LITE, $59.71) makes optical communications devices that help power telecom networks and data center communications equipment, among a wide range of other products. But it's perhaps best known as the company that makes the 3D facial-recognition sensors for Apple's (   AAPL) iPhones.

The relentless growth of cloud-based services bodes well for the data-center businesses of tech stocks such as LITE, as does the build-out of 5G networks. And thanks to last year's acquisition of optical-components maker Oclaro, Lumentum is set to make the most of its chances.

" Our Buy rating on shares of LITE is based on our expectation that the newly combined Lumentum + Oclaro is better positioned for continued growth in its core telecom optical market, should see improving economics in the datacom market with greater scale and the entry of new lower-cost high-speed products and long-term growth opportunities in 3D sensing," Stifel analysts write.

All 16 analysts surveyed by S&P Global Market Intelligence are bullish on this tech stock - 11 call it a Strong Buy, with the other five at Buy. Their average price target of $71.39 suggests LITE will gain 20% over the next 12 months or so.

SEE ALSO: What Is Apple's " Next iPhone"?

Top-Rated Big Tech Stock #4: Autodesk

Market value: $32.1 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.76

Autodesk (ADSK, $145.95) is by far and away the Big Kahuna when it comes to software that allows architects, engineers, manufacturers - you name it - to design complicated projects in three dimensions.

Investors are getting a bit hinky about the slowdown in the global economy, but these macro concerns haven't put a damper on analysts' enthusiasm for ADSK stock. At least not yet. We'll get more clarity after the computer-assisted design company posts quarterly results, currently slated for Aug. 27. Generally, a slowdown in manufacturing is not good for Autodesk.

Keybanc analysts recently surveyed Autodesk's North American resellers. The takeaway was that the software company should hit its quarterly numbers. Keybanc reiterated its Overweight (Buy) rating on shares. Longer-term, Stifel, which calls shares a Buy, likes ADSK's opportunities in 3D printing and increasing use of digital design in the architecture, engineering and construction industries.

Out of 25 analysts polled by S&P Global Market Intelligence, 14 rate ADSK at Strong Buy, four say Buy, six have it a Hold and one says Sell. Their average target price of $184.29 gives shares implied upside of 26% over the next year to 18 months.

SEE ALSO: 10 Top Stocks That Show Gender Diversity Counts

Top-Rated Big Tech Stock #3: PayPal

Market value: $129.2 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.75

To say PayPal (PYPL, $109.82) garners a lot of interest on the part of Wall Street analysts would be an understatement. More equity research shops keep tabs on the digital payments company than Microsoft (   MSFT), the world's largest publicly traded company by a wide margin.

Fully 40 analysts cover PayPal, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. They're bullish: 21 rate PYPL at Strong Buy, nine say Buy, nine have it at Hold and one says Sell.

Shares in PayPal have tumbled about 9% after hitting an all-time high in late July. The culprit? The company cut its full-year revenue outlook when it posted second-quarter results. Shares had been a white-hot tear heading into the earnings release, which set them up for a significant drawdown on anything less than a perfect report. (The broader market's tantrum didn't help.)

Analysts aren't fazed. If anything, the recent drop makes PayPal even more attractive. Wedbush rates the stock at Outperform based on " continued hyper growth from mobile payment transactions," the ramping up of Venmo digital wallet and contributions from Xoom money transfer service.

With an average target price of $127.51, PYPL stock has implied upside of 16%. Analysts expect earnings to grow at an average annual pace of almost 19% over the next three to five years.

SEE ALSO: 6 Tech Stocks to China-Proof Your Portfolio

Top-Rated Big Tech Stock #2: Fiserv

Market value: $73.4 billion

Dividend yield: N/A

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.64

Digital payments, payments processors and pretty all things to do with financial tech are hot these days. Even Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B), whose CEO and Chairman is the typically tech-averse Warren Buffett, is making multimillion-dollar investments in fintech.

Fiserv (FISV, $107.56) is not a   Berkshire holding as of this writing, but it does exemplify much of what Buffett likes about companies that facilitate financial transaction processing - ample opportunities for growth and economies of scale.

FISV, which recently acquired First Data in a $22 billion all-stock transaction, certainly has the scale part working in its favor.

" We specifically like the company's positioning, acting as a strategic partner to large and small community banks undergoing dramatic transformation in their business model (shifting to digital-like services)," write Wedbush analysts, who rate FISV stock at Outperform.

Of the 25 analysts covering FISV tracked by S&P Global Market Intelligence, 16 rate the stock at Strong Buy, four say Buy, four call it a Hold and one holdout says it's a Strong Sell.

SEE ALSO: 10 Top-Rated Mega-Cap Stocks to Buy Now

Top-Rated Big Tech Stock #1: Microsoft

Market value: $1.06 trillion

Dividend yield: 1.3%

Analysts' average recommendation: 1.46

It's no surprise that sitting atop this list of analyst-loved tech stocks is Microsoft (MSFT, $138.79). The folks in Redmond, Washington, have been killing it for some time now. The software king's cloud-computing business has propelled a long-sleepy stock into the stratosphere.

As noted above, Microsoft is the world's biggest publicly traded company and the only one with a market value of at least $1 trillion. No. 2 Apple, a massive stock in its own right, trails MSFT by around $100 billion in market capitalization.

Canaccord Genuity analysts, who rate shares at Buy, write the " juggernaut is set to continue" thanks to Microsoft's arsenal of growth drivers that include Azure cloud computing, Office 365 and the Xbox gaming ecosystem.

" When we hear investors get jumpy because MSFT continues to advance in 'beast mode,' we suggest they relax and enjoy what looks to us to be several more years of above-average growth and price appreciation," Canaccord Genuity writes.

Of the 35 analysts tracked by S&P Global Market Intelligence, 23 have MSFT at Strong Buy, 10 say Buy, one calls it a Hold ... and one bear is hanging on to a Strong Sell call. Perhaps most impressively for a trillion-dollar company, earnings are forecast to grow an average of more than 12% a year for the next three to five years - not an easy feat for such a gigantic corporation.

urn:contentItem:5B61-R3K1-JB5M-W0B9-00000-0013 tech stories that mattered in 20132013-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:42ZLexisNexis13 tech stories that mattered in 2013Sambit Satpathy

The year 2013 is almost over and with only a few hours before we usher in 2014, it is that time again when we look back at all those fond or not-so-fond memories this past year. Our industry has had a roller coaster ride in 2013 with numerous ups and downs and a few bumps in between. Letas take a look at the top 13 tech stories that mattered in 2013.

Steve Ballmer retires as Microsoft CEO

One of the most recognizable figures in the tech industry a" Microsoftas CEO Steve Ballmer a" shocked the world when he announced that he would be retiring in 12 months. The loud and often eccentric man whose keynotes had more drama than TV soaps was going to step down after more than a decade at the helm. The industry in general was sad to see such a character leave and his tearful farewell to his colleagues showed just how much he was going to miss the spotlight. His announcement also kickstarted the ongoing race to find the next CEO, which has thrown up some big names like Alan Mulally, Satya Nadella and Nokiaas own Stephen Elop among others.

Microsoft to acquire Nokiaas devices and services unit

After months of speculations, Microsoft finally announced that it had finally stuck a deal with Nokia and was going to acquire the Finnish companyas devices and services unit for $7.2 billion. What followed was a whole lot of analysis, speculations and the drama only intensified when Nokiaas Stephen Elop was suddenly in contention to become Microsoftas next CEO. Later in the year, Nokiaas shareholders, the EU regulators and the US Justice Department gave the deal their thumbs-up. The Indian tax case was also resolved before the final date to decide on the fate of the Chennai manufacturing plant. The only thing standing between the two companies is the green signal from China.

BlackBerry puts itself up for sale but fails to get a buyer

BlackBerry was another company which was up for sale, but unlike the Nokia-Microsoft saga, BlackBerryas deal with Fairfax Financial fell apart at the last moment. The failed deal also saw CEO Thorsten Heins booted out of the company and being replaced by John Chen. The companyas fortunes though didnat turn for the good and it saw huge losses, layoffs and even its move to release BlackBerry Messenger (BBM) on multiple platforms didnat change things. The release created a lot of interest initially, but soon fizzled out and many concluded that the move was atoo little too latea. Chen yesterday released an open letter talking about BlackBerry in 2014 and its manufacturing deal with Foxconn but few expect the company to make a turnaround. Will BlackBerry survive 2014 is the billion dollar question on everyone's mind.

HTCas downward spiral

Another company, which had a torrid year, was Taiwanese HTC. A company, which was once a major player, has seen its market share shrink to a measly 3-4 percent. Though it is credited with having launched the One, which is one of the best Android devices you can buy today, high pricing and delays in shipments saw it lose to its immediate rival a" the Samsung Galaxy S4. Things only got worse as the year progressed with the company investigating certain employees for having allegedly stolen and subsequently sold company secrets. There were layoffs, CEO Peter Chou was put under tremendous pressure and also saw the company suffering its first every quarterly loss.

Twitter IPO

Not all companies had a bad time though. Twitter, for one, can look back at 2013 fondly having become the latest big tech-startup to go public. Unlike Facebookas IPO though, Twitter enjoyed a good start opening at $45.10 and also reaching a record high of $71.65 last week. Though the company is making good money from the NYSE listing, we will wait to see how it uses the resources to improve the service.

Yahoo juggernaut under Marissa Mayer

Ever since taking over as the CEO of the company, Marissa Mayer has been busy trying to revive the huge brand that Yahoo once was. In about seven months, Mayer has acquired around two dozen startups and companies in a bid to completely refresh its ageing products. Some results were immediately visible, with Yahooas iOS weather app receiving a lot of positive feedback and also winning Appleas prestigious Design Award. Other acquisitions though are a part of a long term plan as Mayer tries to rejuvenate the Yahoo brand and make it more suitable for the contemporary crowd. One of her biggest acquisitions was Tumblr, which is said to have cost the company around a billion dollars.

Apple-Samsung patent war

The year also saw legal battles being fought between companies and the most publicized of all was the patent war between Samsung and Apple. The back and forth between the two companies over the former allegedly copying the latteras iPhone design saw a lot of trials, re-trials and appeals and both companies saw victories and defeats. The first round was won by Apple where it was awarded $1 billion in damages, Samsung won the next round at the ITC, and later this year Samsung again lost an appeal and was ordered to pay Apple an additional $290 million in damages. If recent reports are to be believed, the two companies have finally started talks to resolve their differences outside the court. Let's see if 2014 turns out to be the year when more drama happens at store shelves than courtrooms.

Hacktivison - hacking/defacing websites and twitter handles

We witnessed quite a few attacks on the websites of government agencies, news publications, on private user account information and also the act of defacing various websites. Some of the biggest attacks were carried out by the Syrian Electronic Army (SEA), which defaced many news publications like Huffington Post, NY Times, BBC,A Thomson Reuters, Telegraph, Associate Press, FT, The Onion among others and also hacked and gained access to user information on Twitter, Truecaller and Viber.

NSA snooping

Another highly controversial series of events was related to National Security Agency (NSA), one of the premier security agencies of the United States. It was revealed that NSA was spying on various computers and telecommunication medium, which was a blatant breach of a personas privacy. Whistleblower Edward Snowden made this revelation, and it shook the very foundations of the democratic government in the country. Later reports revealed that at one point NSA had hacked into and was snooping on more than 50,000 computer networks globally. The revelations will have long-term impact, especially with countries taking steps to secure "their" Internet possibly leading to Balkanization of the World Wide Web. Snowden's leaks about the part many tech companies like Google, Facebook, Apple, Microsoft and others play will also have a significant impact.

The rise and fall of Bitcoins

Virtual currency bitcoin gained a lot of prominence this year and with it the value of the currency went through the roof. Recently, the value of a single bitcoin was equal to a staggering $1,000. People who had forgotten or given up on the currency suddenly found themselves rich. One such man in Britain who had disposed his hard disk containing bitcoins realized (a bit too late, we might add) that his collection was worth millions of pounds. The currency though, has received far from a warm welcome globally and in India, the RBI has deemed the virtual currency illegal and doesnat allow any kind of transactions in the country.

Year of the wearable devices

The evolution of tech has always seen devices become smaller and slimmer than before and this was the year when smart devices became small enough to fit on oneas wrist. That said, this category always had promise but failed to deliver. The most talked about Samsung Galaxy Gear smartwatch was only an expensive piece of glass and plastic and Google Glass is nothing more than a field project. Other smartwatches like Pebble, Sony Smartwatch 2 or Qualcomm Toq havenat done any better either and health-related smart devices like Nike FuelBand and FitBit too have a long way to go. Hopefully, in the coming year, we will get to see a breakthrough product from companies like Google or Apple or even an improved product from Samsung that could kickstart this genre in a big way.

Gaming console wars

When talking about tech, gaming cannot possibly be left out of discussion. 2013 was the year of the next-generation where Sony and Microsoft unveiled and consequently launched the PlayStation 4 and the Xbox One respectively. Any doubts about whether there would be enough buyers for the next-generation consoles considering their high price were laid to rest when both the companies managed to sell more than a million consoles on day one of launch. Since then they have introduced the consoles at other markets around the world and the sales graph is only pointing in one direction a" Up!

Google looks to the future

Google has never been shy about trying to do something, which sounds or looks impossible. But its Google X labs continues to dish out things that would be a mainstay on sci-fi novels. This year, Google introduced the driverless car, acquired Boston Dynamics to build and develop highly intelligent robots in the near future and also announced Project Loona" a highly ambitious project, which will bring Internet connectivity to the world using hot air balloons.

The year 2013 is almost over and with only a few hours before we usher in 2014, it is that time again when we look back at all those fond or not-so-fond memories this past year. Our industry has had a roller coaster ride in 2013 with numerous ups and downs and a few bumps in between. Let's take a look at the top 13 tech stories that mattered in 2013.


Steve Ballmer retires as Microsoft CEO
One of the most recognizable figures in the tech industry — Microsoft's CEO Steve Ballmer — shocked the world when he announced that he would be retiring in 12 months[1]. The loud and often eccentric man whose keynotes had more drama than TV soaps[2] was going to step down after more than a decade at the helm. The industry in general was sad to see such a character leave and his tearful farewell to his colleagues[3] showed just how much he was going to miss the spotlight. His announcement also kickstarted the ongoing race to find the next CEO[4], which has thrown up some big names like Alan Mulally, Satya Nadella and Nokia's own Stephen Elop among others.
Microsoftto acquire Nokia's devices and services unit
After months of speculations, Microsoftfinally announced that it had finally stuck a deal with Nokia and was going to acquire the Finnish company's devices and services unit for $7.2 billion[5]. What followed was a whole lot of analysis, speculations and the drama only intensified when Nokia's Stephen Elop was suddenly in contention to become Microsoft's next CEO[6]. Later in the year, Nokia's shareholders[7], the EU regulators[8] and the US Justice Department[9] gave the deal their thumbs-up. The Indian tax case was also resolved before the final date to decide on the fate of the Chennai manufacturing plant[10]. The only thing standing between the two companies is the green signal from China.
BlackBerry puts itself up for sale but fails to get a buyer
BlackBerry was another company which was up for sale, but unlike the Nokia-Microsoftsaga, BlackBerry's deal with Fairfax Financial fell apart at the last moment[11]. The failed deal also saw CEO Thorsten Heins booted out of the company and being replaced by John Chen[12]. The company's fortunes though didn't turn for the good and it saw huge losses[13], layoffs[14] and even its move to release BlackBerry Messenger (BBM) on multiple platforms[15] didn't change things. The release created a lot of interest initially, but soon fizzled out and many concluded that the move was 'too little too late'. Chen yesterday released an open letter talking about BlackBerry in 2014[16] and its manufacturing deal with Foxconn[17] but few expect the company to make a turnaround. Will BlackBerry survive 2014 is the billion dollar question on everyone's mind.
HTC's downward spiral
Another company, which had a torrid year, was Taiwanese HTC. A company, which was once a major player, has seen its market share shrink to a measly 3-4 percent. Though it is credited with having launched the One, which is one of the best Android devices you can buy today[18], high pricing and delays in shipments[19] saw it lose to its immediate rival — the Samsung Galaxy S4. Things only got worse as the year progressed with the company investigating certain employees for having allegedly stolen and subsequently sold company secrets[20]. There were layoffs, CEO Peter Chou was put under tremendous pressure and also saw the company suffering its first every quarterly loss[21].
Twitter IPO
Not all companies had a bad time though. Twitter, for one, can look back at 2013 fondly having become the latest big tech-startup to go public. Unlike Facebook's IPO though, Twitter enjoyed a good start opening at $45.10[22] and also reaching a record high of $71.65 last week[23]. Though the company is making good money from the NYSE listing, we will wait to see how it uses the resources to improve the service.
Yahoo juggernaut under Marissa Mayer
Ever since taking over as the CEO of the company[24], Marissa Mayer has been busy trying to revive the huge brand that Yahoo once was. In about seven months, Mayer has acquired around two dozen startups and companies in a bid to completely refresh its ageing products. Some results were immediately visible, with Yahoo's iOS weather app receiving a lot of positive feedback and also winning Apple's prestigious Design Award. Other acquisitions though are a part of a long term plan as Mayer tries to rejuvenate the Yahoo brand and make it more suitable for the contemporary crowd. One of her biggest acquisitions was Tumblr, which is said to have cost the company around a billion dollars[25].
Apple-Samsung patent war
The year also saw legal battles being fought between companies and the most publicized of all was the patent war between Samsung and Apple[26]. The back and forth between the two companies over the former allegedly copying the latter's iPhone design saw a lot of trials, re-trials and appeals and both companies saw victories and defeats. The first round was won by Apple where it was awarded $1 billion in damages, Samsung won the next round at the ITC, and later this year Samsung again lost an appeal and was ordered to pay Apple an additional $290 million in damages[27]. If recent reports are to be believed, the two companies have finally started talks to resolve their differences outside the court. Let's see if 2014 turns out to be the year when more drama happens at store shelves than courtrooms.
Hacktivison - hacking/defacing websites and twitter handles
We witnessed quite a few attacks on the websites of government agencies, news publications, on private user account information and also the act of defacing various websites. Some of the biggest attacks were carried out by the Syrian Electronic Army (SEA)[28], which defaced many news publications like Huffington Post, NY Times, BBC, Thomson Reuters[29], Telegraph, Associate Press, FT, The Onion among others and also hacked and gained access to user information on Twitter, Truecaller[30] and Viber[31].
NSA snooping
Another highly controversial series of events was related to National Security Agency (NSA), one of the premier security agencies of the United States. It was revealed that NSA was spying on various computers and telecommunication medium, which was a blatant breach of a person's privacy. Whistleblower Edward Snowden made this revelation, and it shook the very foundations of the democratic government in the country. Later reports revealed that at one point NSA had hacked into and was snooping on more than 50,000 computer networks globally[32]. The revelations will have long-term impact, especially with countries taking steps to secure 'their' Internet possibly leading to Balkanization of the World Wide Web. Snowden's leaks about the part many tech companies like Google, Facebook, Apple, Microsoftand others play will also have a significant impact.
The rise and fall of Bitcoins
Virtual currency bitcoin gained a lot of prominence this year and with it the value of the currency went through the roof. Recently, the value of a single bitcoin was equal to a staggering $1,000. People who had forgotten or given up on the currency suddenly found themselves rich. One such man in Britain who had disposed his hard disk containing bitcoins[33] realized (a bit too late, we might add) that his collection was worth millions of pounds. The currency though, has received far from a warm welcome globally and in India, the RBI has deemed the virtual currency illegal and doesn't allow any kind of transactions[34] in the country.
Year of the wearable devices
The evolution of tech has always seen devices become smaller and slimmer than before and this was the year when smart devices became small enough to fit on one's wrist. That said, this category always had promise but failed to deliver. The most talked about Samsung Galaxy Gear smartwatch[35] was only an expensive piece of glass and plastic and Google Glass is nothing more than a field project. Other smartwatches like Pebble[36], Sony Smartwatch 2[37] or Qualcomm Toq[38] haven't done any better either and health-related smart devices like Nike FuelBand and FitBit too have a long way to go. Hopefully, in the coming year, we will get to see a breakthrough product from companies like Google[39] or Apple[40] or even an improved product from Samsung that could kickstart this genre in a big way.
Gaming console wars
When talking about tech, gaming cannot possibly be left out of discussion. 2013 was the year of the next-generation where Sony and Microsoftunveiled and consequently launched the PlayStation 4[41] and the Xbox One respectively. Any doubts about whether there would be enough buyers for the next-generation consoles considering their high price were laid to rest when both the companies managed to sell more than a million consoles[42] on day one of launch[43]. Since then they have introduced the consoles at other markets around the world and the sales graph is only pointing in one direction — Up!
Google looks to the future
Google has never been shy about trying to do something, which sounds or looks impossible. But its Google X labs continues to dish out things that would be a mainstay on sci-fi novels. This year, Google introduced the driverless car, acquired Boston Dynamics to build and develop highly intelligent robots[44] in the near future and also announced Project Loon[45]— a highly ambitious project, which will bring Internet connectivity to the world using hot air balloons.

Makan Delrahim, the U.S. prosecutor leading the regulatory probe of tech giants like Facebook (FB) and Google (GOOG, GOOGL), said at the WSJ Tech Live summit earlier that everything is "perfectly on the table," according to a recent WSJ story. "Big is not bad." Big behaving badly is bad," said "Delrahim at the WSJ event. The Wall Street Journal has reported that U.S. Attorney General William Barr, "is pushing a broad antitrust review looking at Facebook, Alphabet, Amazon (AMZN) and Apple (AAPL). urn:contentItem:5DYB-13F1-F03R-N421-00000-0014 for '14: Xconomy's Top Innovation Stories of the Year2014-12-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:42ZLexisNexis14 for '14: Xconomy's Top Innovation Stories of the Year

Dec 29, 2014 (Xconomy:http://www.xconomy.com/ Delivered by Newstex)
Gregory T. Huang It has been quite a year for one-word headlines: Ebola, Sony, Uber, WhatsApp, to name a few.
Behind those headlines are complex issues in business and technology that came to the fore in 2014. Things like impediments to vaccine development; mounting threats in cybersecurity and privacy; the regulatory and cultural struggles of high-flying startups; and intensifying battles between companies trying to win the future of markets like mobile, advertising, and healthcare.


At Xconomy we live to bring you news, features, and analysis on important topics like these, from the front lines of where things are actually happening. Our reporters are in 10 regions and counting, and they aim to deliver local stories with global impact.
The following are my picks for Xconomy's top stories of 2014. If you read only a few articles this year, read these. If you want to know the deeper stories behind the headlines, read these. If you want to take the pulse of innovation communities that don't always get a lot of attention, read on. Each piece provides the context, national significance, and close-to-the-scene access that you couldn't get anywhere else.
Here are the stories from around our network, in reverse chronological order:
1. Houston's Bellicum Pharma Rides T-Cell Therapy Wave to $140M IPO[1]
The first Houston biotech to go public in over a decade is part of a wave of cancer immunotherapy companies (see Juno and others), as Angela Shah reports.
2. Startups and 13 States Jumpstart Equity Crowdfunding Without SEC[2]
The world of startup crowdfunding is changing fast, with different rules in different states; Michael Davidson sorts it all out.
3. New Ag-Biotech Initiative Plants Seeds for Startups[3]
There's something brewing in North Carolina agricultural tech; Frank Vinluan gives the historical context for an important new partnership.
4. So Far, Little Proof That Digital Health Is Healthy. Does It Matter?[4]
As health IT starts to go mainstream, Alex Lash asks a critical question—and ponders the future of healthcare.
5. Startups, Jobs, Economic Impact: An Analysis of Commercialization at UW[5]
Ben Romano's in-depth look at the commercialization business at the University of Washington—with lessons, perhaps, for other schools.
6. John Maraganore: From 'Prototypical Geek' to Canny Alnylam Chief[6]
Ben Fidler's signature profile of one of the biggest names in biotech, complete with scientific twists and turns and business opportunities lost and won.
7. Mapp Bio Steps onto Global Stage as Ebola 'Hot Zone' Gets Hotter[7]
A San Diego biotech company rises to prominence following the worst Ebola outbreak in history, as Bruce Bigelow reports.
8. What's After Big Data? Niche Analytics, Data Wrangling, Smart Storage[8]
My look at the future of 'big data,' and where startups are heading in their efforts to outmaneuver traditional powers like IBM and EMC.
9. Sexism and Misogyny in Tech: How Investors Can Help Drive Change[9]
J.P. Ruth tackles one of the hot-button topics of the year, and asks some constructive questions of startups and their investors.
10. Udacity's Nanodegrees: Edtech's Challenge to College Credentials?[10]
Bernadette Tansey peers into the future of job training and sees that big tech companies want a piece of the education market.
11. Don't Want Google in Your House? Some Home-Tech Startups to Watch[11]
When Google bought Dropcam for half a billion dollars, Curt Woodward took a look at competing startups that have, shall we say, lower privacy costs.
12. Madison's Tech Future: 5 Ways It Could Succeed, 5 Ways It Could Fail[12]
Jeff Engel's on-the-ground look at the pros and cons of a small but lively startup cluster—with plenty of challenges that apply elsewhere.
13. Ingress, Google, and Linda Besh: How a Mobile Game Augments Reality[13]
Sarah Schmid runs with Detroit mobile gamers and their leader, who has come to Google's attention through the virtual world.
14. WhatsApp, $19 Billion, and the Unreal Economy of Silicon Valley[14]
The biggest tech acquisition of the year leads Wade Roush to question the fundamentals of the industry.
Honorable mention (a half-dozen wildcards; plenty of others I missed):
Vecna CTO Builds Solar-Powered Volkswagen Bus—And It Actually Works[15]
Biotech Startups Tap Spider Genes in Quest to Spin Silk Gold[16]
Steve Wozniak on Galaxy Gear, Google Glass, Future of Wearables[17]
Bluebird's Gene Therapy Quickly Halts Blood Disease in Small Study[18]
This Boston Lawyer Could Be Uber's Nemesis as It Eyes Expansion[19]
Can Sacramento End Its Innovation Drought?[20]
International Wild Card:
And if you are interested in an up and coming international innovation cluster, check out our special report (21 stories all told) on Innovation in Ireland[21].

urn:contentItem:60G4-BK91-JCMN-Y10B-00000-0015 books that explain how the American economy became a mess — and why we need 'better capitalism'2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:41ZLexisNexis15 books that explain how the American economy became a mess — and why we need 'better capitalism'Marguerite Ward,Nick Lichtenberg,Richard Feloni

Jul 29, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) https://www.businessinsider.com/better-capitalism Business Insider's Better Capitalism[1] series focuses on why inequality has been hurting economic growth, and why new approaches to business and policy can be a course correction.Today, Congress is grilling the big tech CEOs about antitrust for the first time.We've listed books like "Goliath" by Matthew Stoller and "The Meritocracy Trap" by Daniel Markovits that make sense of how we got to this point.This article is part of Business Insider's ongoing series on Better Capitalism[2]. Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[3]There's been a shift in corporate America over the past few years toward equality and accountability.Leaders are increasingly being held accountable for not only their role in the economy, but in society, as evidenced by Wednesday's Congressional hearing with big tech CEOs like Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg and Amazon's Jeff Bezos. The executives will face questions on whether they're hampering innovation and contributing to a fair society.The move toward accountability gained speed in August 2019, when nearly 200 CEOs of America's largest companies declared their companies exist for the "benefit of all stakeholders[4]— customers, employees, suppliers, communities and shareholders." This collection of CEOs, the lobbying group the Business Roundtable, rejected the idea that maximizing shareholder value at all costs will take care of everything else.Their statement was not legally binding, but even if it ends up merely symbolic, it marks a significant shift in the conversation.

Since the beginning of last year, Business Insider has been exploring the momentum behind this shift — why we need "Better Capitalism[5]," as we call it, and how we can achieve it.Our series started with the rejection of the shareholder primacy theory that grew in popularity in the late 1970s and became the norm beginning in the '80s. That theory led to a short-term focus on profits above all else, and we're arguing that this has come at the expense of other stakeholders, and has been a significant factor in the country's out-of-control wage-and-wealth inequality.We've found that there is an increasingly loud call to tie profits to purpose, and it's not just a moral argument, especially today amid the coronavirus pandemic and nationwide calls for racial justice.To make sense of where we are today and where we should be headed, we've gathered some of our favorite books on the economy and the role of business in society.This is an updated version of a story that ran on March 16, 2019. 'Transaction Man' by Nicholas Lemann The shift in the conversation Americans are having about capitalism has direct ties to the financial crisis and the ensuing populist movements, but its roots are in the American economy's rise to dominance following World War II.Nicholas Lemann, a New Yorker staff writer and professor and dean emeritus at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, takes a look at how the US economy got to where it is right now. [Full disclosure, a contributor to this article, Richard Feloni, attended the school of journalism when Lemann was the dean.]He explores how the theories of shareholder primacy and trickle-down economics led to, as the subtitle of the book captures, "the rise of the deal and the decline of the American Dream." And it's not simply theoretical. Lemann makes his narrative resonate through the stories of both those who have thrived and those who have suffered through the past several decades in America. Find it here [6] 'The Enlightened Capitalists' by James O'Toole O'Toole, the founding director of the University of Southern California's Neely Center for Ethical Leadership and Decision-Making, chronicles the ways business leaders tried to align their profits with social good, sometimes with poor results.Using case studies of entrepreneurs behind brands like J.C. Penney and Levi Strauss & Co., O'Toole examines what works and what doesn't when it comes to building sustainable, socially-conscious companies. Find it here [7] 'The Shareholder Value Myth' by Lynn Stout The late Cornell Law professor Lynn Stout rose to prominence challenging the ideas that have dominated the past 40 years. In 2012, she took on the theory of shareholder primacy, which is the idea that public companies exist above all else to serve the needs of shareholders, and that if they make decisions with this approach, customers and employees will naturally benefit.There's an argument to be made that this approach may have made sense in the 1980s, after the stagflation of the '70s, but Stout shows that it was inherently flawed and achieving the opposite result. Shareholder primacy can benefit investors in the short term, but it's an approach considering all stakeholders that creates lasting long-term value for investors, as well. Find it here [8] 'Rewriting the Rules of the American Economy' by Joseph Sitglitz Joseph Stiglitz is a Nobel Prize-winning economist based at Columbia University, and his 2015 book looks at how shareholder primacy has been one of many policies that he believes have been hurting the American economy.Stiglitz dismisses the argument that implementing policies that would decrease inequality would hinder growth. Instead, he explains, the wealthiest Americans have increasingly captured the benefits of the growth seen in the past few decades, which handicaps the economy from performing at its best. Find it here [9] 'Conscious Capitalism' by John Mackey and Raj Sisodia Whole Foods founder John Mackey and Babson College professor Raj Sisodia kicked off a movement with their 2013 book, "Conscious Capitalism."Stout and Stiglitz used their books to show that prevailing business theories were not only detrimental to workers and communities, but to shareholders and the economy as a whole; Mackey and Sisodia use theirs to show that businesses were already in a position to link their profits to purpose, and that investing in all stakeholders also increased the bottom line. Find it here [10] 'Winners Take All' by Anand Giridharadas Anand Giridharadas is a journalist and former McKinsey consultant who was fully enmeshed in the world of the elite. As an Aspen Institute Fellow, he was a true believer in "doing well by doing good." But by 2015, he felt like everything was built on a charade.In his book, Giridharadas gives a scathing critique of how countries like the United States have essentially handed over societal problems to corporations and billionaires, without addressing the roots of the issues.We're using our list to highlight ways that those in power can better use that power, but Giridharadas' book is an important wake-up call that will ensure you are always conscious of the bigger picture. Find it here [11] 'Janesville' by Amy Goldstein We're in the early stages of another major shift in industry, where advances in technology will be both replacing and creating millions of new jobs. New solutions around job retraining and skills-based education will play a vital role in ensuring the changes benefit as many people as possible, but "Janesville" also shows there are no quick fixes.Washington Post reporter Amy Goldstein reported extensively in Janesville, Wisconsin[12], from 2011 to 2017, tracking the struggles of a town after its General Motors plant closed. Her findings included the insight that when we talk about "closing the skills gap," we must be very deliberate about the path from training to job. It will require the cooperation of educators, politicians, corporations, and labor. Find it here [13] 'This Changes Everything' by Naomi Klein We've been focusing on how the neoliberal policies of the past 40 years have negatively impacted people, but reporter and activist Naomi Klein's 2014 book focuses on how those same policies of growth at all costs have also ravaged the planet.The literature on the harmful effects of climate change is extensive, but "This Changes Everything" specifically focuses on the role business has played, and why citizens must demand that significant moves toward sustainability are enforced. Find it here [14] 'Crashed: How a Decade of Financial Crises Changed the World' by Adam Tooze The debate over the role of public companies, the wealthy, and policy in America has been waged for decades, but it's begun a new phase as the generation that entered the workforce during the financial crisis has come of age.Columbia historian Adam Tooze offers perhaps the most extensive explanation of the crisis itself, its causes, and ramifications, and how what happened in the American financial system was closely linked to the crisis that shook Europe. Find it here [15] 'Capital in the 21st Century' by Thomas Piketty French economist Thomas Piketty had an unexpected best-seller when his 800-page economics book was published in English in 2013.It's still the gold standard on understanding how we've come to a new Gilded Age. Find it here [16] 'The Curse of Bigness' by Tim Wu Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren has breaking up big tech in her presidential campaign platform, and it's based on a growing movement of economists and lawyers pushing for enhanced antitrust law.Columbia law professor and former Federal Trade Commission adviser Tim Wu has provided the most succinct and persuasive case for why we should revitalize antitrust, to weaken the effects increased market concentration is having on workers, politics, and customers. Find it here [17] 'The Big Nine' by Amy Webb "Artificial intelligence" is a ubiquitous but often misunderstood buzzword when we discuss the future of business.New York University professor Amy Webb is here to help. She breaks down how "The Big Nine" developers of AI are shaping our futures, but that nothing they create has inevitable ramifications.She uses data and history to show what's actually happening in the world of AI, dispelling both excessive fear and optimism[18], and proposes ways that countries and corporations will have to work together to create regulations and expectations around increasingly powerful technology. Find it here [19] 'The Third Wave' by Steve Case There are different ways of categorizing the industrial shift we're in — there's a debate over whether it qualifies as "the Fourth Industrial Revolution" — but it's undeniable that technological changes are transforming the way we work.AOL founder and venture capitalist Steve Case sees this period as the beginning of "The Third Wave of the Internet,"[20] following the first wave of foundational internet companies like AOL and second wave companies like Facebook.We're headed into a world where "the internet of things" will become the internet of everything, and Case believes that this is going to more evenly distribute the power concentrated in Silicon Valley and Wall Street. It's why he's investing in rising startup scenes throughout the country, which he thinks will be critical to the future success of the American economy. Find it here [21] 'The Meritocracy Trap' by Daniel Markovits A meritocrat turns on his own class in this provocative read. The book argues that the American Dream that was built on a post-aristocracy mindset has actually replicated aristocracy by another name: meritocracy.Daniel Markovits, a Yale Law School professor, enhances in this book an argument he first gave in a 2015 commencement speech[22] at the same school. In short, he argues that elite American workers, typified by lawyers, have driven increasing inequality by commanding ever higher wages. These "meritocrats" work longer hours than other Americans, for greater outcomes, leading to an unhealthy situation for them, for the increasingly underpaid and underworked majority of workers, and for the economy as a whole.It's anunprecedented accomplishment in human history that the richest Americans overwhelmingly work for a living, and he argues it requires an unprecedented solution. Find it here [23] 'Goliath' by Matthew Stoller Monopoly isn't just a board game, it's the enemy of democracy, as Matthew Stoller puts it in his 2019 book "Goliath," which highlights "concentrated financial power" as the major culprit. Whether a monopoly is US Steel or Amazon or Google, the end result is bad for the democratic political system, he argues.Stoller is a fellow at the Open Markets Institute but is better known for his voluble Twitter presence[24], his substack newsletter[25], and before this book, his essay published on the virtual eve of the 2016 election in The Atlantic: "How Democrats Killed Their Populist Soul."[26]In the essay and the book it inspired, Stoller brings his own perspective as a former Capitol Hill staffer to the story of how the Democratic Party began to embrace the financial sector in the 1970s, leading to what he argues were disastrous results. The New Deal of the 1930s, he argued, broadly redefined American politics in general, and the Democratic Party in particular, as distrustful of concentrations of power. But the Democrats of today forgot its lessons.The book ranges much farther afield than the financial sector, exposing what Stoller calls "the 100-year war" between democracy as a political system and its opposite: monopoly power. President Franklin Roosevelt, in his telling, built off the previous era of "trust-busting" to investigate concentrated power in the housing, newsprint, steel, fertilizer, and tobacco, industries, to name just a few. urn:contentItem:60HG-V1B1-JCSC-J28J-00000-0015 Ways Tech Leaders Can Support Important Industry Legislation2020-08-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:42ZLexisNexisNEWS15 Ways Tech Leaders Can Support Important Industry LegislationExpert Panel

As legislation regarding cybersecurity, user data and other tech topics become more widely discussed and understood, tech leaders are keeping their eyes on political headlines. The decisions made by lawmakers can set the precedent for responsible (or irres... As legislation regarding cybersecurity, user data and other tech topics become more widely discussed and understood, tech leaders are...

As legislation regarding cybersecurity, user data and other tech topics become more widely discussed and understood, tech leaders are keeping their eyes on political headlines. The decisions made by lawmakers can set the precedent for responsible (or irres...

As legislation regarding cybersecurity, user data and other tech topics become more widely discussed and understood, tech leaders are keeping their eyes on political headlines. The decisions made by lawmakers can set the precedent for responsible (or irresponsible) technology use, so tech professionals need to get involved and speak up to bring the right topics and policies on the table. We asked the members of Forbes Technology Council to share some advice for politically minded industry leaders who want to make sure appropriate and effective tech legislation is passed. Their best answers are below. 1. Read articles from multiple sources every day. Reading domestic and world headlines is a regular part of my day, but it’s not with the goal of weighing in and influencing the right decision. In tech/security, there may be several right answers. I like consuming them all from different source types so that I can gain perspective. It helps me understand potential audiences better. - Joe Morin , CyFlare 2. Do your part by building good products and services. Build honest and genuinely good products and services. Honesty is the best policy, and it is very important that you build and support solutions for the larger good of people in the society and country at large. Ensure you are backing ethical and citizen-centric platforms and policies. - Vishwa Prasad , People Tech Group Forbes Technology Council is an invitation-only community for world-class CIOs, CTOs and technology executives. Do I qualify? 3. Support existing initiatives. Build credibility gradually by supporting existing projects. Getting involved in legislative discussions as a technologist carries some risks. If you are serious about participating, focus on finding common ground between your agenda and broader concerns. You can enter this debate gradually by sponsoring existing public initiatives like National Cybersecurity Awareness Month in October. - Nelson Cicchitto , Avatier Corporation 4. Balance innovation with an awareness of potential harm. The question of regulating tech is at the forefront these days — an example is San Francisco’s ban on facial recognition. When it comes to legislation and policy, it is not enough to think about how one rule applies to all but how can we balance innovation with actual harm. Understanding different countries’ laws is equally important, because the United States’ Fourth Amendment does not exist in China or South Korea. - Swathi Young , Integrity Management Systems Inc. 5. Use your expertise to help protect the public. In the First, Third, Fourth and Fifth Amendments, the U.S. Constitution implicitly grants a right to privacy against governmental intrusion. Therefore, it’s imperative that cybersecurity is in compliance with the protection of privacy. As tech leaders, we should be vocal, especially since the public doesn’t share our level of expertise. It’s incumbent upon us to sound the alarm on such matters. - Frank Speiser , Talla 6. Emphasize the importance of cybersecurity. A federal cyber-disaster assistance program is needed. This will put the severity, magnitude and importance in its proper perspective. Cyberattacks are not going away, and I expect them to get much worse. Expect the types of cybercrimes in healthcare to become terrifying. Until cybersecurity is “marketed” correctly, it will not get the attention that it deserves. - Will Conaway , The HCI Group/Tech Mahindra 7. Be a part of the legislative process. Big tech leaders understand that, in general, “If you’re not sitting at the dinner table, you’re next on the menu.” Accordingly, the only way for leaders to make sure that the “right” tech-focused legislation is passed is to be part of the legislative process. Whether through expert testimony, public debate and opinion building, leaders can shape this process by being a proactive part of it. - Ahmad (Al) Fares , CeliTech Inc. 8. Be informed and get involved. Tech leaders who want to be involved in policies or need to be involved due to the type of work we do (in our case, face detection is a hot topic out there) need to make sure that we are first of all informed about what is going on in Washington — but also we need to be involved. We have chosen to become involved with organizations that guide decisions. - Mercedes Soria , Knightscope 9. Foster open communication to reach consensus. Keep an open mind and realize that numbers represent power. Invest in the occasional town hall meeting with your employees. Urge them that free thinking is promoted and that an open mindset is a plus. Once there is an agreement among the majority, we can tip the scales of democracy and hopefully get the right legislation passed. With more people comes more influence, both around the state and around the country. - WaiJe Coler , InfoTracer 10. Promote the benefits of technology solutions. Be outspoken about what good your technology can bring to society and life in your country. If politicians notice you and keep you in the back of their minds, they will think about the benefits of implementing your solutions when passing certain legislations. - Daria Leshchenko , SupportYourApp Inc. 11. Encourage politicians to consider the worst-case scenario. Encourage every politician to watch Black Mirror on Netflix. That’s no joke. Our leaders need to be able to imagine the butterfly effect of societal change that can be wrought by new tech legislation. Whether they’re draconian or overly permissive, misguided tech laws move us closer to a truly dystopian future, so we need to make sure that politicians understand that they’re playing with fire. - Chris Turlica , MaintainX Inc. 12. Focus first on industry standards and guidelines. Work on guidelines and standards for the industry first, which will help uninformed or non-tech legislators better understand what to do next. The tech industry is still pretty lawless, so unless we legislate ourselves, laws are always going to benefit those rich enough to hire lobbyists. More importantly, they’ll ignore the rights and needs of the users. - Thomas Griffin , OptinMonster 13. Avoid ethically questionable income. Put your money where your mouth is. If you want to get involved in the political implications of something, make sure you’re willing to walk the walk. Refuse the ethically sticky money even if it’s legal. - Tim Conkle , The 20 14. Consider both industry and user needs. For politically minded tech leaders to ensure the right legislation is passed, they must consider the desires and needs of both the industry and its users. It’s vital that leaders have an objective, balanced perspective on any issue involving technology, as well as any implications that arise from implementing a particular solution. It’s tough to do this, but all opinions must be accounted for. - Marc Fischer , Dogtown Media LLC 15. Reach out to industry peers and legislators. As a tech leader, you have a right to be involved in the aspects of the legislation that will impact your business. Therefore, make sure to be involved. Contact those who are drafting the legislation, join groups that align with your point of view, and reach out to your fellow tech businesses and let them know the impact the legislation will have and why they should speak up. Get involved! - Alexandro Pando , Xyrupt Technologies

value.Title: 16:51 EDT Japan seeks to levy stronger data regulation on big tech firms, NAR says

Extracts.SummaryText: ... regulation on big tech firms, NAR says Major technology firms like Google ( GOOGL ), Facebook ( FB ), Netflix ( NFLX ), and Amazon ( AMZN ) will face harsher rules on handling personal data in Japan, which looks to use antitrust law to stop unfair trade-offs between privacy and free services, Nikkei Asian Review's Kosuke Takeuchi reports. urn:contentItem:5VX7-7BP1-JCD8-M3DF-00000-0016:51 EDT Japan seeks to levy stronger data regulation on big tech firms, NAR says2019-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:42ZLexisNexis16:51 EDT Japan seeks to levy stronger data regulation on big tech firms, NAR says

Major technology firms like Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), Netflix (NFLX), and Amazon (AMZN) will face harsher rules on handling personal data in Japan, which looks to use antitrust law to stop unfair trade-offs between privacy and free services, Nikkei Asian Review's Kosuke Takeuchi reports. The Japanese government seeks to form a plan for stronger regulation of so-called platform providers as soon as midyear, Takeuchi says. The policy would incorporate the idea of "abuse of a superior bargaining position," which the Asian nation has so far applied only to business-to-business relationships, the author notes. [Reference Link]:[https://asia.nikkei.com/Economy/Big-Tech-to-face-antitrust-law-on-user-data-in-Japan]|

urn:contentItem:5X5W-S4W1-JCD8-M271-00000-0016:55 EDT Comcast wades into antitrust pile-on against Google, Reuters says2019-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:42ZLexisNexis16:55 EDT Comcast wades into antitrust pile-on against Google, Reuters says

16:55 EDT Comcast wades into antitrust pile-on against Google, Reuters says - Comcast (CMCSA) has joined the large regulatory pile-on against big tech companies such as Google (GOOG), Reuters' Paresh Dave and Sheila Dang report, citing people familiar with the matter. Behind the closed doors of a congressional task force a month ago, the media giant's video ads unit FreeWheel accused Google of using privacy concerns as a pretext to limit FreeWheel's ability to sell ads on behalf of its clients' YouTube channels, the authors say, citing four people briefed on the discussion. Comcast wants to avoid letting the Alphabet unit do to the video ad industry what it has done to the online ad market, the authors note. "FreeWheel would embrace a solution that allowed it to continue to meaningfully serve its clients when they publish their content on YouTube, as it had for over a decade on that platform," Comcast said in a statement. "Unfortunately, the actions to remove or degrade FreeWheel's capabilities on YouTube fall well short of that." [Reference Link]:[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-comcast-alphabet-antitrust-exclusive-idUSKBN1WG3J7?utm_campaign=trueAnthem:+Trending+Content&utm_content=5d93bc2fb1a00400017b6d74&utm_medium=trueAnthem&utm_source=twitter]

urn:contentItem:5X2M-T911-DYWB-B125-00000-0016:57 EDT U.S antitrust regulators bicker over big tech probe, WSJ reports2019-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:06:41ZLexisNexis16:57 EDT U.S antitrust regulators bicker over big tech probe, WSJ reports

John McKinnon and Brent Kendall of the Wall Street Journal write that both U.S federal antitrust enforcers, the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department's antitrust division are both trying to "assert authority to investigate whether big technology companies are engaging in anticompetitive behavior." The WSJ story points out that late last week the FTC complained about the Justice Department's antitrust division's "behavior" and raised questions "about recent interactions between the two agencies." Companies that may be impacted by this news include, Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOG), Netflix (NFLX), Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT). [Reference Link]:[https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-antitrust-enforcers-signal-discord-over-probes-of-big-tech-11568663356]|
